results.title: Billy's helicopter ride
results.brief_description: Introduces the helicopter and its uses through the story of a young boy taking his first ride. Gives children an opportunity to experience second-hand what they might never experience themselves.

results.title: The Billiard room
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Joe Scully, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adults Learning”.
Designed to promote group discussion on the problems of the adult learning process in management-staff relations through a discussion between a potential university dropout, his friend and an onlooker. It suggests that not all learning occurs in the classroom. This film should not be screened by itself as a documentary. It does not provide direct information on the process of adult learning. It is a teaching aid which provides a basis for discussion.

results.title: Bill Tilden's advanced tennis
results.creator_credit: Julian Peyser and New Official Films
results.brief_description: Bill Tilden narrates and demonstrates advanced techniques of tennis, including net game, foot work, smash, service and volley. Front, back, aside and overhead views permit study of his playing technique from a variety of angles.

results.title: Bill Loosley's heat pump
results.creator_credit: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shows thermal engineer Bill Loosely’s simple design for beating the high costs of heating. Animation and explanations by Loosely himself are used to show how he used copper tubing and freon gas to collect warmth from the ground outside and pump it through his house. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Bike people
results.creator_credit: Phil Kassel and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: More and more people are riding bikes today, and here the basic safety precautions, optional equipment and protection against theft are discussed. The film explains bike vehicle code rules which are designed to make riding safe and fun, and points out that equipment can add to safe riding.

results.title: A Bike, a birthday
results.brief_description: Almost every young child longs for a shiny new bike. One youngster, Jay, wishes for and has a marvellous adventure in his dream about this prize possession. But until the morning of his birthday, Jay doesn’t know whether or not his birthday gift is the treasured first bike. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Bighorn!
results.creator_credit: Robert Riger, Eleanor Riger and Tomorrow Entertainment
results.brief_description: Hosted by John Denver, this program considers the habitat and behavior of the Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep and shows how the lives of the sheep are being threatened by the activities of man. Denver speaks and sings of the oneness with the world he feels during his trip through the mountains and of how people must relearn to respect nature, her laws and inhabitants. The trip covers the period from early spring through winter, and many animals are glimpsed and discussed. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Bighorn!
results.brief_description: Focuses on problems facing wildlife and wilderness areas in the United States. Gives the history of the Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep and describes its relationship to its environment. This film was made with the assistance of Yellowstone National Park, Glacier National Park and Grand Teton National Park.

results.title: The Biggest bug
results.creator_credit: Austral Pacific Productions and British Petroleum
results.brief_description: A film made for the Keep Australia Beautiful Council. A satirical attack on the practice of dumping rubbish and a plea to Australians to preserve the beauty of their country. A family picnics in a suburban garden and leaves it as littered as many people do when picnicking in the country. The film ends with the well-known slogan “Don’t rubbish Australia”! Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
